Concepts.definition: To use again.
Something that establishes or serves as a pattern for reference; a form, mold, or pattern used as a guide to making something.

An active process; excludes processes and mechanisms which fulfill biological functions.

ValueDomain.preferredName: PCORnet CDM General Observation Terminology Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Terminology / vocabulary used to describe the clinical observation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A code used for PCORNet network-wide activities related to general observation data.

Concepts.definition: A code used for PCORNet network-wide activities related to general observation data.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An individual who uses a computer, program, network, or related service for work or entertainment.: A concise explanation of the meaning of a word or phrase or symbol.

Concepts.definition: An individual who uses a computer, program, network, or related service for work or entertainment.
A concise explanation of the meaning of a word or phrase or symbol.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).: Preparations containing substances with antigenic properties administered to activate the immune system, thereby inducing an immune response.

Concepts.definition: The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).
Preparations containing substances with antigenic properties administered to activate the immune system, thereby inducing an immune response.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A system of internationally agreed generic descriptors used to identify all medical device products.

Concepts.definition: A system of internationally agreed generic descriptors used to identify all medical device products.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A system that provides normalized names for generic and branded drugs and that functions as a tool to support interoperability between terminologies. RxNorm is produced by the National Library of Medicine.

Concepts.definition: A system that provides normalized names for generic and branded drugs and that functions as a tool to support interoperability between terminologies. RxNorm is produced by the National Library of Medicine.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An international organization of scientists involved in human genetics. Established in 1989 by a collection of the world's leading human geneticists, the primary ethos of the Human Genome Organisation is to promote and sustain international collaboration in the field of human genetics.

Concepts.definition: An international organization of scientists involved in human genetics. Established in 1989 by a collection of the world's leading human geneticists, the primary ethos of the Human Genome Organisation is to promote and sustain international collaboration in the field of human genetics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized vocabulary of phenotypic abnormalities encountered in human disease.

Concepts.definition: A standardized vocabulary of phenotypic abnormalities encountered in human disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A multiaxial, hierarchical classification system for diseases in man developed by the College of American Pathologists.

Concepts.definition: A multiaxial, hierarchical classification system for diseases in man developed by the College of American Pathologists.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: International Classification of Diseases for Oncology

ValueMeaning.preferredName: International Classification of Diseases for Oncology
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The International Classification of Diseases for Oncology has been used for nearly 25 years as a tool for coding diagnoses of neoplasms in tumor and cancer registrars and in pathology laboratories. ICD-O is a dual classification with coding systems for both topography and morphology. The topography code describes the site of origin of the neoplasm. The morphology code describes the characteristics of the tumor itself, including its cell type and biologic activity. (from Amazon.com)

Concepts.longName: International Classification of Diseases for Oncology
Concepts.definition: The International Classification of Diseases for Oncology has been used for nearly 25 years as a tool for coding diagnoses of neoplasms in tumor and cancer registrars and in pathology laboratories. ICD-O is a dual classification with coding systems for both topography and morphology. The topography code describes the site of origin of the neoplasm. The morphology code describes the characteristics of the tumor itself, including its cell type and biologic activity. (from Amazon.com)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The International Classification of Diseases, Eleventh Revision, Clinical Modification/Procedure Coding System is the U.S. health system's adaptation of international ICD11 standard list of six-character alphanumeric codes used in hospital inpatient settings for inpatient procedure coding.

Concepts.definition: The International Classification of Diseases, Eleventh Revision, Clinical Modification/Procedure Coding System is the U.S. health system's adaptation of international ICD11 standard list of six-character alphanumeric codes used in hospital inpatient settings for inpatient procedure coding.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The International Classification of Diseases, Tenth Revision, Clinical Modification/Procedure Coding System is the U.S. health system's adaptation of international ICD-10 standard list of six-character alphanumeric codes used in hospital inpatient settings for inpatient procedure coding.

Concepts.definition: The International Classification of Diseases, Tenth Revision, Clinical Modification/Procedure Coding System is the U.S. health system's adaptation of international ICD-10 standard list of six-character alphanumeric codes used in hospital inpatient settings for inpatient procedure coding.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An extension of the ICD-9 created by the U.S. National Center for Health Statistics so that the system could be used to capture more morbidity data. This extension included a section of procedure codes.

Concepts.longName: International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision, Clinical Modification
Concepts.definition: An extension of the ICD-9 created by the U.S. National Center for Health Statistics so that the system could be used to capture more morbidity data. This extension included a section of procedure codes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A proprietary medical nomenclature of the American Medical Association widely used to report medical procedures and services under public and private health insurance programs.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: A standardized coding system used by Medicare and other health insurance programs to ensure that claims are processed in an orderly and consistent manner. The coding system comprises the procedure codes of the American Medical Association Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) and an additional standardized coding set that is used primarily to identify products, supplies, and services not included in the CPT codes.

Concepts.definition: A proprietary medical nomenclature of the American Medical Association widely used to report medical procedures and services under public and private health insurance programs.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

Concepts.longName: Healthcare Financing Administration Common Procedure Coding System
Concepts.definition: A standardized coding system used by Medicare and other health insurance programs to ensure that claims are processed in an orderly and consistent manner. The coding system comprises the procedure codes of the American Medical Association Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) and an additional standardized coding set that is used primarily to identify products, supplies, and services not included in the CPT codes.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Published by the The Regenstrief Institute, the Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes covers clinical and clinical laboratory terminology.

Concepts.longName: Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes
Concepts.definition: Published by The Regenstrief Institute, the Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes covers clinical and clinical laboratory terminology.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A unique numeric code assigned by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to prescription drugs and insulin products manufactured, prepared, processed, or propagated by registered establishments for commercial distribution. U.S. prescription drugs must use an NDC; most non-prescription drugs are also primarily referenced by NDC. NDC codes change often as companies merge, new products are introduced, and drugs are retired.  Each code is a unique 10-digit, 3-segment number in one of the following configurations: 4-4-2, 5-3-2, or 5-4-1. The first, labeler code segment is assigned by the FDA to identify the establishment. The second, product code segment identifies a specific strength, dosage form, and formulation for a particular firm. The third, package code segment identifies package sizes and types. Both the product and package codes are assigned by the establishment. An asterisk may appear as a placeholder in the second or third segments.

Concepts.definition: A unique numeric code assigned by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to prescription drugs and insulin products manufactured, prepared, processed, or propagated by registered establishments for commercial distribution. U.S. prescription drugs must use an NDC; most non-prescription drugs are also primarily referenced by NDC. NDC codes change often as companies merge, new products are introduced, and drugs are retired.  Each code is a unique 10-digit, 3-segment number in one of the following configurations: 4-4-2, 5-3-2, or 5-4-1. The first, labeler code segment is assigned by the FDA to identify the establishment. The second, product code segment identifies a specific strength, dosage form, and formulation for a particular firm. The third, package code segment identifies package sizes and types. Both the product and package codes are assigned by the establishment. An asterisk may appear as a placeholder in the second or third segments.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
